topic.title: A hypothetical tale about a bad actor on ZeroNet
topic.body:
Imagine for a moment, if you will, a bad actor on the ZeroNet network.

This bad actor decides he wants to cause a little chaos. He creates a few dozen zites. Most of them are empty, showing the default empty zite page you'd get when you create it from ZeroHello. Others are innocent enough, maybe a blog promising some insightful posts in the future weeks, a couple GifTime clones with animal gifs.

As we see these zites being published, hapless ZeroNet users such as you or myself become excited over the influx of new users and new content, and visit these pages and begin seeding them.

Imagine now 6 months have passed, enough time where we have forgotten all about these zites. They once promised good content, but perhaps the owners lost interest? We still seed them, but we forget they are there and pay no attention to them.

The bad actor hasn't lost interest. He decides he's going to push some updates to these dormant zites of his. He publishes content on each of them that would be illegal in most places people can live. This content is automatically downloaded by every hapless ZeroNet user who had not bothered to delete the zite.

Each and every hapless ZeroNet user still seeding these malicious zites are now unknowingly possessing and seeding illegal content from the hard drive on their home computer or phone sd card. It may take some of them several months before they realize this. They might not find every malicious zite that did this to them. For others perhaps they discovered too late, perhaps some LEAs found out first.

The bad actor sits in shadows on his office chair and laughs sinisterly while scratching behind his purring cat's ears.

This story is fictional, but it does concern me. Is there something ZeroNet can do to protect its users against this type of threat? Is there something that ZeroNet users can do to protect themselves on their own?

topic.title: UN Proposal to Ban Fictional Works as "Child Pornography"
topic.body:
The United Nations is asking for feedback on a [new set of proposals](https://www.ohchr.org/EN/HRBodies/CRC/Pages/DraftGuidelinesOPs.aspx) for the international community to rally against child prostitution, the sale of children, and child pornography.

## Sounds great, right?

But a close look at their definition of child pornography reveals that this extends a little bit beyond that. [Drawings, cartoons, written stories, sculptures, and other forms of fictional works](https://www.oneangrygamer.net/2019/02/u-n-proposes-initiative-to-ban-loli-shota-and-underage-drawings-and-cartoons/77229/amp/) are also tucked in under the guise of "child pornography".

A progressive new CSA (child sexual abuse) prevention organization, Prostasia Foundation, recently did [an excellent writeup](https://prostasia.org/blog/experts-to-united-nations-hentai-ban-would-be-a-mistake/) on this UN proposal.

## **This ban may be counterproductive at preventing CSA**

There is no evidence that banning fictitious works has this effect. [Some experts](http://www.sexologytoday.org/2017/02/canada-and-australia-now-have-both.html) do [believe](https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2016/01/can-child-dolls-keep-pedophiles-from-offending/423324/) bans, such as what the UN guidelines as written seek to ban, could actually lead to a rise in CSA.

With zero evidence that banning these things helps children, and with experts fearing that bans like this could put children in jeopardy, it is absolutely premature to implement such a ban until the necessary research has been conducted.

there is no evidence that banning fictitious works has any impact on reducing CSA (child sexual abuse). [some](http://www.sexologytoday.org/2017/02/canada-and-australia-now-have-both.html) [experts](https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2016/01/can-child-dolls-keep-pedophiles-from-offending/423324/) believe that bans on the types of things these UN guidelines seek to ban will actually lead to a rise in CSA.

## **This ban is a gross violation of freedom of speech and expression**

This will have chilling effects.

Most anime, which frequently features high school aged characters, will fall under fire for having "underage" characters depicted. Novels, comics, fanfiction, art, fanart, sculptures, and other creative works featuring characters that "appear underage" (aka under 18) will similarly be harmed by the implementation of these international guidelines.

Websites operating in countries that follow these UN guidelines may find themselves reluctant to support anime or artist communities, since their duty to police content will become even more strict. We have seen the chilling effects on speech that puritan policies such as this have (see: Reddit's [harsh subreddit bans](https://piunikaweb.com/2019/02/12/reddit-facing-massive-public-outcry-after-alleged-loli-crackdown/), Steam's [removal of adult games featuring high school aged girls](https://nichegamer.com/2018/12/06/all-ages-modified-vn-hello-good-bye-banned-on-steam/)).

## **We need to tell the UN that fictional children are not children**

Although the UN's intentions are surely noble, equating artwork to child pornography is a farce which undermines the very concept of harm that CP creation and dissemination has on children, and a slap in the face to survivors of childhood sexual abuse, whose very real depictions of abuse and trauma continue to circulate throughout the internet.

Anyone who would like to join me in presenting opposition to parts of the UN's proposal can do so. They are accepting comments by email. **Comments must be submitted by 31 March 2019.**

* You can [email the UN](crc@ohchr.org) directly, following their [guidelines on submissions](https://www.ohchr.org/EN/HRBodies/CRC/Pages/DraftGuidelinesOPs.aspx).
* Prostasia has created a [form to submit a pre-written email](https://prostasia.org/campaign/art-not-csem/) signed in your name.

**If you are an active member in anime or artist communities, please help spread the word about this issue. Together, we can convey to the UN and the international community why this new attack on free speech will not be tolerated.**

[ZeroMedium post](/ZeroMedium.bit/?/1FzZsDQdh8wk71bDLxURPzmAt2FXehoNAB/un-proposal-to-ban-fictional-works-as-child-pornography)

1_1H8x2Aeu28Lnj6vhXFNZ32kpvGS6dnqWGA.body:
It's potentially really cool. But I don't know how trustworthy it is to use over tor (or i2p) while retaining anonymity. I'm also leery about how every site needs to run js (it can't be helped, i guess!) Some of the developer posts on github also lead me to believe that this anonymity and security is not a very high priority to them.

Everything also seems to be set up to use only one identity on all sites. The identity it asked me to post on here is the same I used on ZeroMe and ZeroMail and everywhere else that required an identity (even an anonymous imageboard!) I don't know if I can even make a new one without deleting my entire ZeroNet profile and starting over. It seems I can only be one person on ZeroNet, which is counter to the way people participate on the public internet.

Very mixed feelings, but its still neat that I can publish something, send it to a bunch of peers, turn my computer off, and people will still access it. It's like freenet but not ancient. Everything about the UI is hipster millennial garbage though.

I've only been using it for a couple of days and that's what I think about ZeroNet so far.

> [gremious](#comment_13_1H8x2Aeu28Lnj6vhXFNZ32kpvGS6dnqWGA): You can use multiple identities, all you have to do is
That sounds really complicated!
It's frustrating that, in the software's default 'this-is-how-people-should-use-what-we-made' state, the ability to have two different identities has been disabled. It's like they're saying people SHOULDN'T be doing that.
Maybe it's just culture shock for me since I've always gravitated toward services where I can click a button and generate a new id. And maybe the way this function works will change over the course of the software's development.

> [mrsrobotmobile](#comment_2_1HsgZpHaZ5BRUK5qr2YMWnubgKyNuSqokH): Obviously.. We won't ever be able to weed out all the apples..but it would be great if more zite owners were proactive about moderating their content. Just so that zeronet proxy owners can host a few porn sites here and there.. and let adults enjoy themselves without too much drama..without having to blacklist Every single site with the keywords Porn in it. [...]

Have you considered that that particular site operator wished to have that kind of content posted?
And while members of the ZeroNet community SHOULD be proactive and do what is best for the "community", it is also true that ZeroNet is a public tool that anyone can pick up and use to do whatever they want with. ZeroNet is not and should not be designed to weed out "bad apples" in that sense.

This means everyone else has to be the responsible and proactive. If you run a service that hosts content published on sites you don't have the ability to control, you have to be a defensive administrator and be proactive to prevent abuse of your service. That includes knowing what the hell you are mirroring and making available to everyone else.

Other viewers likely ARE seeding content they don't know about. They may have since deleted or "believed" they deleted it without realizing some files are still being seeded. These are the risks people may or may not know they are taking when they run ZeroNet. Perhaps nofish needs to be more proactive in educating people about these risks?

At the end of the day though, anyone can publish anything on ZeroNet, and ZeroNet is designed to make it very hard for what is published to be censored and made unavailable. You may consider yourself a member of the community surrounding ZeroNet, but someone who may wish to make a CP website may not think themselves as belonging to a community, and they will likely act in such a way that is harmful to the public image of the network.

You cannot stop them from doing that because ZeroNet is designed to enable them to do that. All that you can do is think and act proactively with this threat model in mind.

Furthermore, if there even WAS the ability to stop anyone from publishing CP on ZeroNet, doing so would be in direct conflict with ZeroNet's goals of being uncensorable and accessible to everyone.

1514422899_1FzZsDQdh8wk71bDLxURPzmAt2FXe.body:
A blacklist feature will definitely help clean up illegal or offending content after its discovery, and will likely prove to be a very valuable tool for users. A weakness of this, however, is that it cannot be used to protect users until after illegal or offensive content has been discovered and possibly saved on their hard drive.

I believe that if contents of the data directory were encrypted, it could significantly aid in protecting users from the damage that might result from this type of attack. I also believe having ZeroNet encrypt and decrypt its data directory with a password or key can be implemented in a user friendly way so that ZeroNet does not become more difficult for people to learn how to use.

However, it can also be said that the users can take this security precaution themselves with commonly available cryptography tools. I also do not know the legal ramifications for users in various oppressive countries might be if ZeroNet implemented this kind of encryption as a feature. Additionally, implementing this feature adds cumbersome requirements onto its developer which would detract from improving and adding to the core features of the software.

With that all said, I do believe this feature would be beneficial to individuals in oppressive countries who understand the legal risks of using cryptographic software, but who are not technologically knowledgeable in how to use cryptographic tools on their own. However, it is also a fact that having encrypted content on your computer is not very helpful in countries where the mere use of cryptography is a violation of law.

while it won't fix all your problems, a consistent sleep schedule is beneficial to anyone's mental well being. sleeping pills are a tool which can be used to correct or maintain a sleep schedule, although they are not necessarily the best tool for the job.

if you want to achieve and maintain mental wellness, sleep is a good place to start. but you should also take note of your diet and physical exercise.

none of these things will benefit you unless you want to make changes for yourself. they also won't make everything in your life right. difficult things in life won't suddenly become easy. but allowing yourself to have a better quality of life will strengthen your mind and make it easier for you to pursue the things you enjoy.

1519690191_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnz.body: the only person who can remove posts or content is the person who holds the private key for signing a site. on zerotalk, it would be nofish. on zerome, it is not nofish (the person who runs Me.ZeroNetwork.bit), but rather the individual who runs the hub that the person published the content to (ZeroMe pulls the things we post from these hub sites, but does not itself host the data we post). so on ZeroMe, the person who wields the power to ban, remove, modify, or otherwise censor content is the operators of the various ZeroMe hub sites we all made accounts on.

so if your hope is to avoid child porn or fake news, my only suggestion is to not be trolled by fake news and to not participate in unmoderated zites or hubs (which is not very useful advice because few zites tell you who operates them, or if they are actively moderated)

1532889245_1NBvhfRTw3aBnasNwmSJ4YBWeRhnx.body:
i2p bote quite possibly provides the most security and anonymity. an adversary would have an incredibly difficult time determining when you have sent or received a message, much less who you are sending/receiving messages to/from. if you send a message through bote you can be pretty confident that only you and the recipient know about it. bote is great for email-like communications, but the latency is incredibly high (i think it can take an hour or longer for a message to be delivered) and if you add an attachment that's more than a few kilobytes your message might never be successfully delivered.

retroshare is neat and useful for filesharing, but it's not anonymous. retroshare is designed to be used by a circle of people who trust each other. friends, family, coworkers, maybe a small internet community. it's not really designed to be used to communicate with strangers over the internet, although now you can run retroshare in tor or i2p-only mode.

> [nicwow](#comment_10_1JHx7fetxzMnUyQ5bUpNLAKAW9VEZdbFMa): If I understand correctly the latency of i2p bote is because of lack of users to store emails. Similar to if all nodes for a particular ZeroNet site went offline. You could potentially pay a VPS to keep you I2p account running. Unless I misunderstand, which is very possible.

i2p is inherently high latency, and bote has a very high latency as a result. this is by design. the end result is that you can't send a bote mail and reasonably expect a reply in under 10 minutes even if the person on the other end is waiting for your message. it isn't like bitmessage where new messages are nearly instant or retroshare where you basically have instant live chat. nor is it like zeromail where you can send an email and get a response in 10 minutes or less assuming the recipient is checking his email.

> [styromaniac](#comment_144_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): I'll either repurpose the site or overwrite it if I don't get pointers, because it's disappointing that it misses out on a useful feature.

you can't and shouldn't be able to make your website force your user's operating system to open programs on their end using javascript. the very thought of this happening makes my hair stand on end.

the best you can do is tell the user's web browser to treat your video file as it would any miscellaneous binary file, which will result either in the file being downloaded and launched by the user's default program they use for that filetype, or the browser will save the file to the user's downloads folder, or the browser will attempt to render the video using its built-in codecs on a new tab.

but the point is its not going to behave the same for every user. you can't just say "click this link to open the video in vlc!" because maybe it wont open in vlc, maybe it will open in mpv. maybe it won't open at all, maybe the file will simply silently get saved to their downloads folder. if they're using an experimental web browser that doesn't conform to web standards maybe it will do something totally unexpected and unpredictable! but the experience will not be the same for every user of your site.

1533843646_1EFHNZxRQ3QB5rhSuKbqVHKo3JMTW.body:
the publish function is used to inform your peers of changes to your site. if you don't have any peers, it can't inform them of changes. publish will not get you any new peers.

your problem isn't that the publish function isn't behaving correctly. the problem is simply that your site doesn't have any peers yet.

-having an open port will help people who are attempting to get to your site reach it and become a peer.
-if nobody is trying to reach your site, you should consider announcing your site on some of these places in this [zerome post](/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1FzZsDQdh8wk71bDLxURPzmAt2FXehoNAB/1530919708)

i just noticed in your log that your zeronet is using tor. if you're using tor-only mode you actually want to keep the port closed, and peers connect to you through tor. don't think about ports. if it says closed, you want it to stay closed.

if you're in mixed tor + clearnet mode you want an open port. if i need to open a port on my home internet i would do so in my router's settings.... but this is not something you normally would need to do unless uPnP isn't working.

1533795431_1As12wFHyZFAw5j8wxKYFaXZbkwLV.body:
this really only seems useful for people who want to help seed other people's sites and posts. most zeronet users do not need to run zeronet 24/7 on a dedicated machine.

this is different from, say, i2p, where it's beneficial to keep the router constantly running to have an improved connection and reachability, or to host a service.

with zeronet you can launch a popular site, get a good amount of peers, and shut down zeronet for months at a time and people will still be able to see your site and make posts to it. the only time you'd need to run zeronet again is if you want to update something on the site (or if you want to see anything others posted, of course)

Also one has to keep in mind even if the js were to be perfectly safe, there are plugins you might have installed(such as flash for example), that can communicate freely using your ip and to whatever server they desire. Js is definitively the most insecure part of zeronet at the moment and the fact that you are required to have js enabled at all times is scary, especially since zite owners are basically gods(in the sense, that they can do anything they want on their zite, including banning and deleting users). At the moment it is impossible to have communication in zeronet without js, since communication with the zeronet client is not possible as soon as you use the /raw/-prefix(/raw/ is the only way you can have access to a zite without js, which, at the current point in time, breaks all zites, that have some sort of communication feature and most other zites, that don't since they rely on js for building the html for the webpage).

1540383456_1DLBhCccN3MbM5YmzNS2UfBzDkEZk.body:
>If everyone want to speak completely freely, they better off maintaining their own zite.
this is the censorship model that zeronet operates under. if you make your own zite, you can say or do whatever you want on it, and you can publish it and have it be distributed and accessible, and individuals or state actors will have a very difficult time stopping you.

i would consider discoverability as a separate issue that ZN doesn't really attempt to solve. just because your zite exists out there doesn't necessarily mean individuals are willing or interested in seeding it, nor does it necessarily mean they will be able to find it. if you advertise it in zeronet on sites you don't operate, those advertisements can be censored.

ZN is also not an equal opportunity seeder. if nobody knows about or cares about your zite, it might in theory be more difficult for people to access it. people seed the sites and data they wish to seed and are not obligated to seed things they don't want to.

i'm not sure, but i think freenet contrasts with this, where users are helping broadcast anything and everything, and the user does not have the capability to pick and choose what they help distribute, nor do they know what they are helping distribute. there are merits and drawbacks to either model.

the ip address associations with an id are only a problem with the id providers which require your ip information. there are totally anonymous id providers out there that do not require any information from you besides a handle you wish to use. ZeroID is not the only id provider. i will concede however that almost every site being developed seems to default to accepting ZeroID and ZeroID only, while ignoring all other ID providers. i wish this were not the case.

i also do not like the ID system to begin with. it is designed in such a way that encourages people to use the same ID on every site. you are pseudo anonymous at best. with a little work anyone can track all your posts down to the one ID you have been using. this would be less  of a problem if ID providers made it easy to generate more than 1 ID, and if ZeroNet or sites had better UI to quickly change the ID you wanted to post with. at the end of the day though, your typing patterns, time of day usage, and various other behavioral factors can make it possible to link different IDs together as belonging to the same individual.

1545029431_1b4WB9mZcpjKdQUnYvGBgTMeatTxX.body:
if zeronet was not secure to use, running it in tor would probably not alleviate the security flaws. all tor does is anonymize your traffic. there has been no third party security audit for zeronet. i don't think there ever will be one?

software like tor or i2p is critical for people who need anonymity, and necessitate that kind of security audit. veracrypt (previously truecrypt) and basically any tool used for encryption, similarly, is pretty critical and needs audits by independent professionals to give reassurance to others that no serious flaws have been discovered in it.

most people who use zeronet use it with their plain old ip address and with no anonymization and don't expect that kind of level of anonymity. many people do use zeronet with tor to provide a layer of anonymity, and assume that tor is anonymizing everything for them and they only need to trust tor. there could be an unknown bug in zeronet that causes a person's real ip address to be exposed even while using tor that no one knows about. but that same risk applies to any software a person might use in conjunction with tor (many bittorrent clients, for instance, leak your real ip address when you try to use tor as a proxy).

if you're worried about your ip address being leaked while using tor only mode, you might want to sniff your traffic to check for these leaks. no one has reported any yet.

if you're worried about javascript breaking through the iframe, i'm afraid i don't know what to tell you. it's a possibility another bug like this will be discovered.

otherwise i'm not sure what you are concerned about in terms of security.

what makes ZN interesting is that a Russian citizen can go abroad for a few months, download a bunch of ZN sites, return to his home country, and Russians can start viewing all the ZN content he acquired while he was out of the country.

they can post content and publish their own things, and as long as that Russian citizen downloaded those Russian posts and content, he can go abroad again and the rest of the world can access those Russian posts.

so as long as Russians are able to travel, and their pc's and devices aren't thoroughly searched, they can still kind of participate in the global ZN network, just not in a live always-online way.

> [xcape2net](#comment_466_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): I2P HTTP Proxy: HTTP/HTTPS client 127.0.0.1 4444 Status is starting.
it's concerning that it says status is "starting", and not "ready" like the others.

> [xcape2net](#comment_467_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): On 127.0.0.1:7657, it gives maybe 10 i2p sites.  I've tried and failed to connect to most of them.  Isn't adding a subscription to my address book just the same thing as adding bookmarks in a regular internet browser?  How would that affect my ability to connect to I2P websites?

adding sites to your addressbook is more like adding a domain name to your hosts file. it is there so you can access i2p sites using convenient human readable domain names like "planet.i2p" instead of their really long b32 address "http://y45f23mb2apgywmftrjmfg35oynzfwjed7rxs2mh76pbdeh4fatq.b32.i2p"

those 10 sites that you see on the router landing page should already be registered in the addressbook though.

if the error you are getting is still "unable to find the proxy server", then it is a problem with either how your proxy is configured in your browser, or a problem with i2p's client tunnel for port 4444 not working. this has no bearing on anything in your addressbook. if it was an issue with not having the site in your addressbook, you'd get a "destination unknown" or some error like that.

1587829097_1Fi8DX6DCYM65akSho5nuAZRmKxn9.body:
uMatrix is great for blocking 3rd party (or even 1st party) requests. i don't think it can be configured to redirect a request to a file on your local filesystem, but it can be used to make absolutely sure a file you don't want to load from an external site cannot be loaded from that external site.

another addon, called Decentraleyes, DOES capture 3rd party cdn requests for /certain/ CDN's, and redirects the browser to fetch those resources from locally copies. this only works for preset CDN's, but the source code is open. you might be able to fork it and modify it to serve the files you want it to.

uMatrix can interfere with Decentraleyes if you block the 3rd party resource, because it precludes Decentraleyes from kicking in and seeing that 3rd party request and then redirecting it to a local file request. so keep that in mind.
